member.name: T:TestR.Internal.Inputs.InputType
member.summary: Specifies the type of the input event. This member can be one of the following values.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.InputType.Mouse

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.InputType.Keyboard
member.summary: INPUT_KEYBOARD = 0x01 (The event is a keyboard event. Use the ki structure of the union.)

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.InputType.Hardware
member.summary: INPUT_HARDWARE = 0x02 (Windows 95/98/Me: The event is from input hardware other than a keyboard or mouse. Use the hi structure of the union.)

member.name: T:TestR.Internal.Inputs.InputTypeWithData
member.summary: The INPUT structure is used by SendInput to store information for synthesizing input events such as keystrokes, mouse movement, and mouse clicks.
member.remarks: This structure contains information identical to that used in the parameter list of the keybd_event or mouse_event function. Windows 2000/XP: INPUT_KEYBOARD supports non-keyboard input methods, such as handwriting recognition or voice recognition, as if it were text input by using the KEYEVENTF_UNICODE flag. For more information, see the remarks section of KEYBDINPUT.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.InputTypeWithData.Type
member.summary: Specifies the type of the input event. This member can be one of the following values. - The event is a mouse event. Use the mi structure of the union. - The event is a keyboard event. Use the ki structure of the union. - Windows 95/98/Me: The event is from input hardware other than a keyboard or mouse. Use the hi structure of the union.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.InputTypeWithData.Data
member.summary: The data structure that contains information about the simulated Mouse, Keyboard or Hardware event.

member.name: T:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardFlag
member.summary: Specifies various aspects of a keystroke. This member can be certain combinations of the following values.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardFlag.ExtendedKey
member.summary: KEYEVENTF_EXTENDEDKEY = 0x0001 (If specified, the scan code was preceded by a prefix byte that has the value 0xE0 (224).)

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardFlag.KeyUp
member.summary: KEYEVENTF_KEYUP = 0x0002 (If specified, the key is being released. If not specified, the key is being pressed.)

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardFlag.Unicode
member.summary: KEYEVENTF_UNICODE = 0x0004 (If specified, wScan identifies the key and wVk is ignored.)

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardFlag.ScanCode
member.summary: KEYEVENTF_SCANCODE = 0x0008 (Windows 2000/XP: If specified, the system synthesizes a VK_PACKET keystroke. The wVk parameter must be zero. This flag can only be combined with the KEYEVENTF_KEYUP flag. For more information, see the Remarks section.)

member.name: T:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardInput
member.summary: The KEYBDINPUT structure contains information about a simulated keyboard event. (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms646271(VS.85).aspx)
member.remarks: Windows 2000/XP: INPUT_KEYBOARD supports nonkeyboard-input methodssuch as handwriting recognition or voice recognitionas if it were text input by using the KEYEVENTF_UNICODE flag. If KEYEVENTF_UNICODE is specified, SendInput sends a WM_KEYDOWN or WM_KEYUP message to the foreground thread's message queue with wParam equal to VK_PACKET. Once GetMessage or PeekMessage obtains this message, passing the message to TranslateMessage posts a WM_CHAR message with the Unicode character originally specified by wScan. This Unicode character will automatically be converted to the appropriate ANSI value if it is posted to an ANSI window. Windows 2000/XP: Set the KEYEVENTF_SCANCODE flag to define keyboard input in terms of the scan code. This is useful to simulate a physical keystroke regardless of which keyboard is currently being used. The virtual key value of a key may alter depending on the current keyboard layout or what other keys were pressed, but the scan code will always be the same.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardInput.KeyCode
member.summary: Specifies a virtual-key code. The code must be a value in the range 1 to 254. If the dwFlags member specifies KEYEVENTF_UNICODE, wVk must be 0.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardInput.Scan
member.summary: Specifies a hardware scan code for the key. If dwFlags specifies KEYEVENTF_UNICODE, wScan specifies a Unicode character which is to be sent to the foreground application.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardInput.Flags
member.summary: Specifies various aspects of a keystroke. This member can be certain combinations of the following values. KEYEVENTF_EXTENDEDKEY - If specified, the scan code was preceded by a prefix byte that has the value 0xE0 (224). KEYEVENTF_KEYUP - If specified, the key is being released. If not specified, the key is being pressed. KEYEVENTF_SCANCODE - If specified, wScan identifies the key and wVk is ignored. KEYEVENTF_UNICODE - Windows 2000/XP: If specified, the system synthesizes a VK_PACKET keystroke. The wVk parameter must be zero. This flag can only be combined with the KEYEVENTF_KEYUP flag. For more information, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardInput.Time
member.summary: Time stamp for the event, in milliseconds. If this parameter is zero, the system will provide its own time stamp.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.KeyboardInput.ExtraInfo
member.summary: Specifies an additional value associated with the keystroke. Use the GetMessageExtraInfo function to obtain this information.

member.name: T:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag
member.summary: The set of MouseFlags for use in the Flags property of the structure.
member.remarks: See: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms646273(VS.85).aspx

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.Move
member.summary: Specifies that movement occurred.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.LeftDown
member.summary: Specifies that the left button was pressed.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.LeftUp
member.summary: Specifies that the left button was released.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.RightDown
member.summary: Specifies that the right button was pressed.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.RightUp
member.summary: Specifies that the right button was released.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.MiddleDown
member.summary: Specifies that the middle button was pressed.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.MiddleUp
member.summary: Specifies that the middle button was released.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.XDown
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Specifies that an X button was pressed.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.XUp
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Specifies that an X button was released.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.VerticalWheel
member.summary: Windows NT/2000/XP: Specifies that the wheel was moved, if the mouse has a wheel. The amount of movement is specified in mouseData.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.HorizontalWheel
member.summary: Specifies that the wheel was moved horizontally, if the mouse has a wheel. The amount of movement is specified in mouseData. Windows 2000/XP: Not supported.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.VirtualDesk
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Maps coordinates to the entire desktop. Must be used with MOUSEEVENTF_ABSOLUTE.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseFlag.Absolute
member.summary: Specifies that the dx and dy members contain normalized absolute coordinates. If the flag is not set, dx and dy contain relative data (the change in position since the last reported position). This flag can be set, or not set, regardless of what kind of mouse or other pointing device, if any, is connected to the system. For further information about relative mouse motion, see the following Remarks section.

member.name: T:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseInput
member.summary: The MOUSEINPUT structure contains information about a simulated mouse event. (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms646273(VS.85).aspx) Declared in Winuser.h, include Windows.h
member.remarks: If the mouse has moved, indicated by MOUSEEVENTF_MOVE, dx and dy specify information about that movement. The information is specified as absolute or relative integer values. If MOUSEEVENTF_ABSOLUTE value is specified, dx and dy contain normalized absolute coordinates between 0 and 65,535. The event procedure maps these coordinates onto the display surface. Coordinate (0,0) maps onto the upper-left corner of the display surface; coordinate (65535,65535) maps onto the lower-right corner. In a multimonitor system, the coordinates map to the primary monitor. Windows 2000/XP: If MOUSEEVENTF_VIRTUALDESK is specified, the coordinates map to the entire virtual desktop. If the MOUSEEVENTF_ABSOLUTE value is not specified, dx and dy specify movement relative to the previous mouse event (the last reported position). Positive values mean the mouse moved right (or down); negative values mean the mouse moved left (or up). Relative mouse motion is subject to the effects of the mouse speed and the two-mouse threshold values. A user sets these three values with the Pointer Speed slider of the Control Panel's Mouse Properties sheet. You can obtain and set these values using the SystemParametersInfo function. The system applies two tests to the specified relative mouse movement. If the specified distance along either the x or y axis is greater than the first mouse threshold value, and the mouse speed is not zero, the system doubles the distance. If the specified distance along either the x or y axis is greater than the second mouse threshold value, and the mouse speed is equal to two, the system doubles the distance that resulted from applying the first threshold test. It is thus possible for the system to multiply specified relative mouse movement along the x or y axis by up to four times.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseInput.X
member.summary: Specifies the absolute position of the mouse, or the amount of motion since the last mouse event was generated, depending on the value of the dwFlags member. Absolute data is specified as the x coordinate of the mouse; relative data is specified as the number of pixels moved.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseInput.Y
member.summary: Specifies the absolute position of the mouse, or the amount of motion since the last mouse event was generated, depending on the value of the dwFlags member. Absolute data is specified as the y coordinate of the mouse; relative data is specified as the number of pixels moved.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseInput.MouseData
member.summary: If dwFlags contains MOUSEEVENTF_WHEEL, then mouseData specifies the amount of wheel movement. A positive value indicates that the wheel was rotated forward, away from the user; a negative value indicates that the wheel was rotated backward, toward the user. One wheel click is defined as WHEEL_DELTA, which is 120. Windows Vista: If dwFlags contains MOUSEEVENTF_HWHEEL, then dwData specifies the amount of wheel movement. A positive value indicates that the wheel was rotated to the right; a negative value indicates that the wheel was rotated to the left. One wheel click is defined as WHEEL_DELTA, which is 120. Windows 2000/XP: IfdwFlags does not contain MOUSEEVENTF_WHEEL, MOUSEEVENTF_XDOWN, or MOUSEEVENTF_XUP, then mouseData should be zero. If dwFlags contains MOUSEEVENTF_XDOWN or MOUSEEVENTF_XUP, then mouseData specifies which X buttons were pressed or released. This value may be any combination of the following flags.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseInput.Flags
member.summary: A set of bit flags that specify various aspects of mouse motion and button clicks. The bits in this member can be any reasonable combination of the following values. The bit flags that specify mouse button status are set to indicate changes in status, not ongoing conditions. For example, if the left mouse button is pressed and held down, MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN is set when the left button is first pressed, but not for subsequent motions. Similarly, MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP is set only when the button is first released. You cannot specify both the MOUSEEVENTF_WHEEL flag and either MOUSEEVENTF_XDOWN or MOUSEEVENTF_XUP flags simultaneously in the dwFlags parameter, because they both require use of the mouseData field.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseInput.Time
member.summary: Time stamp for the event, in milliseconds. If this parameter is 0, the system will provide its own time stamp.

member.name: F:TestR.Internal.Inputs.MouseInput.ExtraInfo
member.summary: Specifies an additional value associated with the mouse event. An application calls GetMessageExtraInfo to obtain this extra information.
